Line 160: Line 160:
Even though the Egyptian constitution provides for the universal freedom of speech (Egypt Constitution, Article 47 - 49),<ref>{{cite news|title=The Constitution of the Arab Republic of Egypt|url=http://www.egypt.gov.eg/english/laws/constitution/default.aspx|accessdate=7 April 2011|year=1971}}</ref> the government frequently sanctioned home raids, torture, arrests, and fining of bloggers and reporters that criticize the government in any way. Under the current state of emergency laws, the government can censor anything if it is considered a threat to âpublic safety and national securityâ. If any reporter or blogger violates this law by criticizing the government, they could be legally penalized with a fine of 20,000 pounds ($3,650) and up to five years in prison. The Moltaqa Forum for Development and Human Rights Dialogue reported that between January and March 2009, 57 journalists from 13 newspapers faced legal penalties for their governmental critiques. The Egyptian government owns stock in the three largest daily newspapers. The government controls the licensing and distribution of all papers in Egypt.<ref>{{cite news|last=U.S. Department of State, Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor|title=Human Rights Report: Egypt|url=http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/nea/136067.htm#|date=11 March 2010}}</ref> The Egyptian government shut down the Internet to most of Egypt during the recent protests in order to limit communication between protest groups.<ref>{{cite news|last=Robertson|first=Jordan|title=The day part of the Internet died: Egypt goes dark|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/jan/28/day-part-internet-died-egypt-goes-dark/|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=28 January 2011}}</ref>
Even though the Egyptian constitution provides for the universal freedom of speech (Egypt Constitution, Article 47 - 49),<ref>{{cite news|title=The Constitution of the Arab Republic of Egypt|url=http://www.egypt.gov.eg/english/laws/constitution/default.aspx|accessdate=7 April 2011|year=1971}}</ref> the government frequently sanctioned home raids, torture, arrests, and fining of bloggers and reporters that criticize the government in any way. Under the current state of emergency laws, the government can censor anything if it is considered a threat to âpublic safety and national securityâ. If any reporter or blogger violates this law by criticizing the government, they could be legally penalized with a fine of 20,000 pounds ($3,650) and up to five years in prison. The Moltaqa Forum for Development and Human Rights Dialogue reported that between January and March 2009, 57 journalists from 13 newspapers faced legal penalties for their governmental critiques. The Egyptian government owns stock in the three largest daily newspapers. The government controls the licensing and distribution of all papers in Egypt.<ref>{{cite news|last=U.S. Department of State, Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor|title=Human Rights Report: Egypt|url=http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/nea/136067.htm#|date=11 March 2010}}</ref> The Egyptian government shut down the Internet to most of Egypt during the recent protests in order to limit communication between protest groups.<ref>{{cite news|last=Robertson|first=Jordan|title=The day part of the Internet died: Egypt goes dark|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/jan/28/day-part-internet-died-egypt-goes-dark/|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=28 January 2011}}</ref>
â   â
===Corruption among government officials===
  â
{{see|Crime in Egypt}}
  â   â
[[Political corruption]] in Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] rose dramatically due to the increased level of control over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: Liberalism, Islam, and Democracy in the Arab World|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> The rise to power of powerful businessmen in the NDP, in the government, and in the People's Assembly led to massive waves of anger during the years of Prime Ministers Ahmed Nazif's government. An example is [[Ahmed Ezz]]'s [[Monopoly|monopolising]] the steel industry in Egypt by holding more than 60% of the market share.<ref name="Emerging Egypt 2007">{{Cite book|title=The Report: Egypt 2007|publisher=[[Oxford Business Group]]|year=2007|month=January|isbn= 1-9023-3957-6}}</ref> Aladdin Elaasar, an Egyptian biographer and an American professor, estimates that the Mubarak family is worth from $50 to $70 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/aladdin-elaasar/egyptians-rise-against-th_b_815520.html |title=Egyptians Rise Against Their Pharoah |work=[[Huffington Post]] |last=Elaasar |first=Aladdin |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/egypt-mubarak-family-accumulated-wealth-days-military/story?id=12821073&page=2|title=Egypt's Mubarak Likely to Retain Vast Wealth|publisher=''[[ABC News]]''|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
The wealth of [[Ahmed Ezz]], the former NDP Organisation Secretary, is estimated to be 18 billion [[Egyptian pound]]s;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions">{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90033584?Obama%20optimistic%20about%20Egypt%20as%20negotiators%20make%20concessions|title=Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions|publisher=AHN|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> the wealth of former Housing Minister Ahmed al-Maghraby is estimated to be more than 11 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions" /> the wealth of former Minister of Tourism [[Zuhair Garrana]] is estimated to be 13 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions" /> the wealth of former Minister of Trade and Industry, Rashid Mohamed Rashid, is estimated to be 12 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions" /> and the wealth of former Interior Minister Habib al-Adly is estimated to be 8 billion Egyptian pounds.<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions" />
  â   â
The perception among Egyptians was that the only people to benefit from the nation's wealth were businessmen with ties to the National Democratic Party; "wealth fuels political power and political power buys wealth."<ref>{{cite web|author=Inside Story |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/insidestory/2011/02/201128111236245847.html |title=How did Egypt become so corrupt? â Inside Story |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
During the [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010]], opposition groups complained of harassment and fraud perpetrated by the government. Opposition and civil society activists have called for changes to [[National Association for Change#Platform|a number of legal]] and [[National Association for Change#Goals|constitutional provisions which affect elections]].{{citation needed|date=April 2011}}
  â   â
In 2010 [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] (CPI) report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref>
 
===Demographic and economic challenges===
===Demographic and economic challenges===
Line 186: Line 173:
[[File:Flickr - Daveness 98 - Cityscape in Cairo.jpg|thumb|A poor neighbourhood in Cairo]]
[[File:Flickr - Daveness 98 - Cityscape in Cairo.jpg|thumb|A poor neighbourhood in Cairo]]
Egypt's economy was highly centralised during the rule of former President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] but opened up considerably under former President Anwar Sadat and Mubarak. From 2004 to 2008 the Mubarak-led government aggressively pursued economic reforms to attract foreign investment and facilitate [[GDP]] growth, but postponed further economic reforms because of global economic turmoil. The international [[economic downturn]] slowed Egypt's GDP growth to 4.5% in 2009. In 2010 analysts said the government of Prime Minister [[Ahmed Nazif]] would need to restart economic reforms to attract foreign investment, boost growth, and improve economic conditions. Despite high levels of national economic growth over the past few years, living conditions for the average Egyptian remained poor,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/egypt/egypt_economy.html|title=Egypt Economy 2011|author= Source: [[CIA World Factbook]] and other sources |accessdate=3 March 2011}}</ref> though better than many other countries in Africa.<ref name="cliodynamics.ru"/>
Egypt's economy was highly centralised during the rule of former President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] but opened up considerably under former President Anwar Sadat and Mubarak. From 2004 to 2008 the Mubarak-led government aggressively pursued economic reforms to attract foreign investment and facilitate [[GDP]] growth, but postponed further economic reforms because of global economic turmoil. The international [[economic downturn]] slowed Egypt's GDP growth to 4.5% in 2009. In 2010 analysts said the government of Prime Minister [[Ahmed Nazif]] would need to restart economic reforms to attract foreign investment, boost growth, and improve economic conditions. Despite high levels of national economic growth over the past few years, living conditions for the average Egyptian remained poor,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/egypt/egypt_economy.html|title=Egypt Economy 2011|author= Source: [[CIA World Factbook]] and other sources |accessdate=3 March 2011}}</ref> though better than many other countries in Africa.<ref name="cliodynamics.ru"/>
  +   +
===Corruption among government officials===
  +
{{see|Crime in Egypt}}
  +   +
[[Political corruption]] in Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] rose dramatically due to the increased level of control over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: Liberalism, Islam, and Democracy in the Arab World|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> The rise to power of powerful businessmen in the NDP, in the government, and in the People's Assembly led to massive waves of anger during the years of Prime Ministers Ahmed Nazif's government. An example is [[Ahmed Ezz]]'s [[Monopoly|monopolising]] the steel industry in Egypt by holding more than 60% of the market share.<ref name="Emerging Egypt 2007">{{Cite book|title=The Report: Egypt 2007|publisher=[[Oxford Business Group]]|year=2007|month=January|isbn= 1-9023-3957-6}}</ref> Aladdin Elaasar, an Egyptian biographer and an American professor, estimates that the Mubarak family is worth from $50 to $70 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/aladdin-elaasar/egyptians-rise-against-th_b_815520.html |title=Egyptians Rise Against Their Pharoah |work=[[Huffington Post]] |last=Elaasar |first=Aladdin |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/egypt-mubarak-family-accumulated-wealth-days-military/story?id=12821073&page=2|title=Egypt's Mubarak Likely to Retain Vast Wealth|publisher=''[[ABC News]]''|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
The wealth of [[Ahmed Ezz]], the former NDP Organisation Secretary, is estimated to be 18 billion [[Egyptian pound]]s;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions">{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90033584?Obama%20optimistic%20about%20Egypt%20as%20negotiators%20make%20concessions|title=Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions|publisher=AHN|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> the wealth of former Housing Minister Ahmed al-Maghraby is estimated to be more than 11 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions" /> the wealth of former Minister of Tourism [[Zuhair Garrana]] is estimated to be 13 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions" /> the wealth of former Minister of Trade and Industry, Rashid Mohamed Rashid, is estimated to be 12 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions" /> and the wealth of former Interior Minister Habib al-Adly is estimated to be 8 billion Egyptian pounds.<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions" />
  +   +
The perception among Egyptians was that the only people to benefit from the nation's wealth were businessmen with ties to the National Democratic Party; "wealth fuels political power and political power buys wealth."<ref>{{cite web|author=Inside Story |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/insidestory/2011/02/201128111236245847.html |title=How did Egypt become so corrupt? â Inside Story |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
During the [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010]], opposition groups complained of harassment and fraud perpetrated by the government. Opposition and civil society activists have called for changes to [[National Association for Change#Platform|a number of legal]] and [[National Association for Change#Goals|constitutional provisions which affect elections]].{{citation needed|date=April 2011}}
  +   +
In 2010 [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] (CPI) report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref>
==Lead-up to the protests==
==Lead-up to the protests==
Line 213: Line 213:
===National Police Day protests===
===National Police Day protests===
â
[[File:Egyptian Flag.png|thumb|A protester holds an Egyptian flag during the protests that started on 25 January 2011 in Egypt]]
+
[[File:The lion of Egyptian revolution (Qasr al-Nil Bridge).jpg|thumb|A protester holds an Egyptian flag during the protests that started on 25 January 2011 in Egypt]]
Opposition groups planned a day of revolt for 25 January, coinciding with the [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]]. The purpose was to protest against abuses by the police in front of the [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Muslim Brotherhood To Participate in 25 January Protest|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/303296|accessdate=8 April 2011|work =[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=23 January 2011}}</ref> These demands expanded to include the resignation of the Minister of Interior, the restoration of a fair [[minimum wage]], the end of [[Emergency law in Egypt|Egyptian emergency law]], and [[term limit]]s for the president.
Opposition groups planned a day of revolt for 25 January, coinciding with the [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]]. The purpose was to protest against abuses by the police in front of the [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Muslim Brotherhood To Participate in 25 January Protest|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/303296|accessdate=8 April 2011|work =[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=23 January 2011}}</ref> These demands expanded to include the resignation of the Minister of Interior, the restoration of a fair [[minimum wage]], the end of [[Emergency law in Egypt|Egyptian emergency law]], and [[term limit]]s for the president.
Line 232: Line 232:
[[File:Tahrir Square - February 9, 2011.png|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protest in [[Tahrir Square]] on 9 February 2011]]
[[File:Tahrir Square - February 9, 2011.png|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protest in [[Tahrir Square]] on 9 February 2011]]
[[File:Tahrir Square on February11.png|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people celebrate in Tahrir Square when Hosni Mubarak's resignation is announced on 11 February 2011]]

â
[[File:Tahrir Square April 01 2011.png|thumb||Hundreds of thousands of demanding trial for [[Hosni Mubarak]], [[Gamal Mubarak]], [[Ahmad Fathi Sorour]], [[Safwat El-Sherif]] and [[Zakaria Azmi]] on 1 April 2011]]
+
[[File:Tahrir Square on April 1 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of demanding trial for [[Hosni Mubarak]], [[Gamal Mubarak]], [[Ahmad Fathi Sorour]], [[Safwat El-Sherif]] and [[Zakaria Azmi]] on 1 April 2011]]
â
[[File:Tahrir Square April 8 2011.png|thumb||Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 8 April 2011]]
+
[[File:Tahrir Square April 8 2011.png|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 8 April 2011]]
â
[[File:Tahrir Square May 27 2011.png|thumb||Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 27 May 2011]]
+
[[File:Tahrir Square on May 27 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 27 May 2011]]
'''25 January 2011''': The '''"Day of Revolt"''': Protests erupted throughout Egypt, with tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Cairo and thousands more in cities throughout Egypt. The protests targeted President Hosni Mubarak's government, and mostly adhered to non-violence. There were some reports of civilian and police casualties.
'''25 January 2011''': The '''"Day of Revolt"''': Protests erupted throughout Egypt, with tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Cairo and thousands more in cities throughout Egypt. The protests targeted President Hosni Mubarak's government, and mostly adhered to non-violence. There were some reports of civilian and police casualties.
Line 620: Line 620:
===The military's role===
===The military's role===
{{see|Egyptian Armed Forces}}
{{see|Egyptian Armed Forces}}
â
[[File:Burning amy vehicle.png|thumb||One of the 2 army vehicles that were burned during the massive army attacks on April 9, 2011.]]
+
{{multiple image
â
[[File:Tahrir Square attacks on April 9 2011.png|thumb||One of the protestors holding some of the army bullets, standing in front of a burning army vehicle that was burned during the army massive attack on April 9, 2011 in Tahrir Square, at least 2 protestors were killed by the army and tens wounded.]]
+
| width1 = 180
  +
| width2 = 180
  +
| align =
  +
| footer = From left to right: One of the 2 army vehicles that were burned during the massive army attacks on April 9, 2011 and one of the protestors holding some of the army bullets, standing in front of a burning army vehicle that was burned during the army massive attack on April 9, 2011 in Tahrir Square, at least 2 protestors were killed by the army and tens wounded.
  +
| image1 = Burning amy vehicle.png
  +
| image2 = Tahrir Square attacks on April 9 2011.png
  +
}}
  +
The [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] enjoy a better reputation with the public than the police does, the former perceived as a professional body protecting the country, the latter accused of [[systemic corruption]] and illegitimate violence. All four [[Egyptian president]]s since the 1950s have come from the military into power. Key Egyptian military personnel include the Defense Minister [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] and General [[Sami Hafez Enan]], Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LC1NLO0.html |title=Key members of Egypt Armed Forces Supreme Council |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=[[Ian Black (journalist)|Black, Ian]]|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-military-hosni-mubarak|title=All Eyes on Egypt's Military as Hosni Mubarak Fortifies Position |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011 |location=London}}</ref> The Egyptian military totals around 468,500 well-armed active personnel, plus a reserve of 479,000.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/30/uk-egypt-protests-military-idUKTRE70T29420110130|title=Factbox â Egypt's Powerful Military|work=[[Reuters]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
The [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] enjoy a better reputation with the public than the police does, the former perceived as a professional body protecting the country, the latter accused of [[systemic corruption]] and illegitimate violence. All four [[Egyptian president]]s since the 1950s have come from the military into power. Key Egyptian military personnel include the Defense Minister [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] and General [[Sami Hafez Enan]], Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LC1NLO0.html |title=Key members of Egypt Armed Forces Supreme Council |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=[[Ian Black (journalist)|Black, Ian]]|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-military-hosni-mubarak|title=All Eyes on Egypt's Military as Hosni Mubarak Fortifies Position |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011 |location=London}}</ref> The Egyptian military totals around 468,500 well-armed active personnel, plus a reserve of 479,000.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/30/uk-egypt-protests-military-idUKTRE70T29420110130|title=Factbox â Egypt's Powerful Military|work=[[Reuters]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
As Head of Egypt's Armed Forces, Tantawi has been described as "aged and change-resistant" and is attached to the old regime. He has used his position as Defense Minister to oppose reforms, economic and political, which he saw as weakening central government authority. Other key figures, Sami Enan chief among them, are younger and have closer connections to both the US and groups such as the Muslim Brotherhood. An important aspect of the relationship between the Egyptian and American military establishments is the 1.3 billion dollars in military aid provided to Egypt annually, which in turn pays for American-made military equipment, and allows Egyptian officers to receive training in the US. Guaranteed this aid package, the governing [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|military council]] is for the most reform-resistant.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/14/wikileaks-cables-egyptian-military-head |title=WikiLeaks cables: Egyptian military head is 'old and resistant to change' |publisher=The Guardian |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |location=London |first1=Julian |last1=Borger |first2=James |last2=Ball}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/feb/04/egypt-arms-trade?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 |title=Egypt's military-industrial complex |publisher=The Guardian |date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |location=London |first=Pratap |last=Chatterjee}}</ref> One analyst however, while conceding that the military is change-resistant, states it has no option but to facilitate the process of democratisation. Furthermore, the military will have to keep its role in politics limited to continue good relations with the West, and must not restrict the participation of political Islam if there is to be a genuine democracy.<ref name="Shlomo Ben Ari"/>
As Head of Egypt's Armed Forces, Tantawi has been described as "aged and change-resistant" and is attached to the old regime. He has used his position as Defense Minister to oppose reforms, economic and political, which he saw as weakening central government authority. Other key figures, Sami Enan chief among them, are younger and have closer connections to both the US and groups such as the Muslim Brotherhood. An important aspect of the relationship between the Egyptian and American military establishments is the 1.3 billion dollars in military aid provided to Egypt annually, which in turn pays for American-made military equipment, and allows Egyptian officers to receive training in the US. Guaranteed this aid package, the governing [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|military council]] is for the most reform-resistant.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/14/wikileaks-cables-egyptian-military-head |title=WikiLeaks cables: Egyptian military head is 'old and resistant to change' |publisher=The Guardian |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |location=London |first1=Julian |last1=Borger |first2=James |last2=Ball}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/feb/04/egypt-arms-trade?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 |title=Egypt's military-industrial complex |publisher=The Guardian |date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |location=London |first=Pratap |last=Chatterjee}}</ref> One analyst however, while conceding that the military is change-resistant, states it has no option but to facilitate the process of democratisation. Furthermore, the military will have to keep its role in politics limited to continue good relations with the West, and must not restrict the participation of political Islam if there is to be a genuine democracy.<ref name="Shlomo Ben Ari"/>
  +   +
===Foreign relations===
  +
{{main|Foreign relations of Egypt}}
  +
Foreign governments in the West including the US have regarded Mubarak as an important ally and [[Foreign relations of Egypt#Israeli-Palestinian conflict|supporter]] in the [[Israeli-Palestinian conflict|Israeli-Palestinian]] peace negotiations.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak" /> After wars with [[Israel]] in 1948, '56, '67 and '73, Egypt signed a [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] in 1979, provoking controversy in the [[Arab world]]. As provisioned in the 1978 [[Camp David Accords]], which led to the peace treaty, both Israel and Egypt receive billions of dollars in aid annually from the United States, with Egypt receiving over US$1.3 billion of military aid each year in addition to economic and development assistance.<ref>{{cite web| title = Background Note: Egypt| publisher=[[United States Department of State]]| date=10 November 2010| url = http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5309.htm| accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> According to Juan Cole, many Egyptian youth feel ignored by Mubarak on the grounds that he is not looking out for their best interests and that he rather serves the interests of the [[West]].<ref name="cole">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/30/opinion/main20030008.shtml|title=Why Egypt's Class Conflict Is Boiling Over â Juan Cole: How Decades of Economic Stumbles Set the Stage for Egypt's Current Political Turmoil|author=Cole, Juan ([[essay]])|date=30 January 2011|work=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> The cooperation of the Egyptian regime in enforcing the [[blockade of the Gaza Strip]] was also deeply unpopular amongst the general Egyptian public.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/jan/25/egypt.israelandthepalestinians1 |title=Mubarak under pressure | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |accessdate=6 February 2011 |location=London |date=25 January 2008}}</ref>
===Online activism and the role of social media===
===Online activism and the role of social media===
Line 667: Line 671:
Though these two are credited with being the first social media faces of this revolution, since the 25th people have posted videos, tweeted, and wrote [[Facebook]] comments to keep the world abreast of the turmoil in Egypt. Including videos posted of a badly beaten Khaled Said, disproving the first claims by the police that he had choked to death.
Though these two are credited with being the first social media faces of this revolution, since the 25th people have posted videos, tweeted, and wrote [[Facebook]] comments to keep the world abreast of the turmoil in Egypt. Including videos posted of a badly beaten Khaled Said, disproving the first claims by the police that he had choked to death.
â   â
===Foreign relations===
  â
{{main|Foreign relations of Egypt}}
  â
Foreign governments in the West including the US have regarded Mubarak as an important ally and [[Foreign relations of Egypt#Israeli-Palestinian conflict|supporter]] in the [[Israeli-Palestinian conflict|Israeli-Palestinian]] peace negotiations.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak" /> After wars with [[Israel]] in 1948, '56, '67 and '73, Egypt signed a [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] in 1979, provoking controversy in the [[Arab world]]. As provisioned in the 1978 [[Camp David Accords]], which led to the peace treaty, both Israel and Egypt receive billions of dollars in aid annually from the United States, with Egypt receiving over US$1.3 billion of military aid each year in addition to economic and development assistance.<ref>{{cite web| title = Background Note: Egypt| publisher=[[United States Department of State]]| date=10 November 2010| url = http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5309.htm| accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> According to Juan Cole, many Egyptian youth feel ignored by Mubarak on the grounds that he is not looking out for their best interests and that he rather serves the interests of the [[West]].<ref name="cole">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/30/opinion/main20030008.shtml|title=Why Egypt's Class Conflict Is Boiling Over â Juan Cole: How Decades of Economic Stumbles Set the Stage for Egypt's Current Political Turmoil|author=Cole, Juan ([[essay]])|date=30 January 2011|work=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> The cooperation of the Egyptian regime in enforcing the [[blockade of the Gaza Strip]] was also deeply unpopular amongst the general Egyptian public.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/jan/25/egypt.israelandthepalestinians1 |title=Mubarak under pressure | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |accessdate=6 February 2011 |location=London |date=25 January 2008}}</ref>
